organization.fullName: Federal University of Health Science of Porto Alegre

identificationModule.briefTitle: Association Between the tDCS and FDS for Gait Rehabilitation After Stroke
identificationModule.officialTitle: Association Between the Transcranial Direct Current Stimulation (tDCS) and Foot Drop Stimulation (FDS) for Gait Rehabilitation After Stroke - A Randomized Clinical Trial

responsibleParty.investigatorAffiliation: Federal University of Health Science of Porto Alegre

leadSponsor.name: Federal University of Health Science of Porto Alegre

descriptionModule.briefSummary: The aim of this study is to verify the effectiveness of tDCS combined with foot drop stimulation (FDS) on gait rehabilitation of post-stroke subjects with mild and moderate compromise.

armGroups.label: ShamtDCS+FDS
armGroups.description: Chronic stroke patients submitted to Foot Drop Stimulation (FDS) + Sham Transcranial direct brain stimulation (tDCS)
interventionNames: Device: Foot Drop Stimulatio - Neuro Orthosis

armGroups.label: tDCS+FDS
armGroups.description: Chronic stroke patients submitted to Foot Drop Stimulation (FDS) + Transcranial direct brain stimulation (tDCS)
interventionNames: Device: Foot Drop Stimulatio - Neuro Orthosis

interventions.name: Foot Drop Stimulatio - Neuro Orthosis
interventions.description: Walkaide is the Foot drop stimulator (FDS) on the peroneal nerve provides active dorsiflexion of muscle during the swing phase of gait.

interventions.name: Transcranial direct brain stimulation
interventions.description: Transcranial direct brain stimulation on motor cortex

primaryOutcomes.description: Evaluated by means of the 3-D motion analysis system (BTS SMART DX 400)
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: The outcome will assess at baseline and two weeks after the intervention. One month later that finished the intensive treatment subjects will re-evaluate.

secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: The outcome will assess at baseline and two weeks after the intervention. One month later that finished the intensive treatment subjects will re-evaluate.

secondaryOutcomes.description: Evaluated by Center of Pressure (COP) displacement assessed on force platform (BTS P-6000)
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: The outcome will assess at baseline and two weeks after the intervention. One month later that finished the intensive treatment subjects will re-evaluate.

secondaryOutcomes.description: Evaluated by means of the Timed Up \& Go Test (TUG)
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: The outcome will assess at baseline and two weeks after the intervention. One month later that finished the intensive treatment subjects will re-evaluate.

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Assessed by means of the Stroke-Specific Quality of Life Questionnaire (SSQOL)
secondaryOutcomes.description:
The SSQOL questionnaire assesses the quality of life of stroke subject, and it contains 49 items with 12 domains (energy, family role, language, mobility, mood, personality, self-care, social role, reasoning, upper limb function, vision and work/productivity). There are three possible answers on the 5-point Likert scale.

The SSOOL questionnaire score reports a minimum of 49 points and a maximum of 245 points. The lower values represent the more dependence and difficulty to perform tasks.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: The outcome will assess at baseline and two weeks after the intervention. One month later that finished the intensive treatment subjects will re-evaluate.

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Muscular tone assessed by the Modified Ashworth Scale
secondaryOutcomes.description: Assessed by the Modified Ashworth Scale. This scale consists of 5 ordinal values ranging from 0 (no tonus increase) to 4 (stiffness).
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: The outcome will assess at baseline and two weeks after the intervention. One month later that finished the intensive treatment subjects will re-evaluate.

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Assessment of Sensorimotor Recovery After Stroke by Fugl-Meyer scale
secondaryOutcomes.description: Fugl-Meyer scale of lower limb impairment. The evaluation includes measurement of voluntary movement, velocity, coordination and reflex activity, through an ordinal scale applied to each item: 0- cannot be performed, 1- partially performed, and 2-performed completely. Participants were also classified according their LL motor impairment in severe (0 to19), moderate (20 to 28) or mild (\> 29 points).
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: The outcome will assess at baseline and two weeks after the intervention. One month later that finished the intensive treatment subjects will re-evaluate.

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Serum levels of Brain-derived neurotrophic fator (BDNF).
secondaryOutcomes.description: The biomarker BDNF will be determined using the enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) method.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: The outcome will be assessed at baseline and 2 weeks after the intervention.

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Serum levels of Insulin-like growth factor binding protein-3 (IGFBP-3)
secondaryOutcomes.description: The biomarker IGFBP-3 will be analyzed in the blood sample to evaluate the neuromuscular adaptations indirectly. Serum IGFBP-3 levels will be determined using the enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) method.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: The outcome will be assessed at baseline and 2 weeks after the intervention.

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Serum levels of insulin-like growth factors 1 (IGF-1)
secondaryOutcomes.description: The IGF-1 will be analyzed in the blood sample to evaluate the neuromuscular adaptations indirectly. Serum IGF-1 levels will be determined using the enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) method.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: The outcome will be assessed at baseline and 2 weeks after the intervention.

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

* Subjects with ischemic or hemorrhagic stroke diagnosis.
* Mild, moderate or severe hemiparesis (chronic stroke - at least 6 months)
* Minimal cognitive ability to understand commands
* Able to walk 10 meters unassisted or with minimal assistance

Exclusion Criteria:

* No current use of antiepileptic drugs for seizures
* Secondary musculoskeletal disorder involving the lower limb
* Contraindication for electrical stimulation

overallOfficials.name: Aline S Pagnussat, PhD
overallOfficials.affiliation: Federal University of Health Sciences of Porto Alegre

locations.facility: Federal University of Health Sciences of Porto Alegre

references.citation: da Cunha MJ, Pinto C, Schifino GP, Sant'Anna Py I, Cimolin V, Pagnussat AS. Bicephalic Transcranial Direct-Current Stimulation Does Not Add Benefits to a Footdrop Stimulator for Improving Functional Mobility in People With Chronic Hemiparesis After Stroke: A Double-Blind, Randomized Controlled Trial. Phys Ther. 2022 Aug 4;102(8):pzac079. doi: 10.1093/ptj/pzac079.
